name: ER and Relational Models
question:
Consider the following relational schema.

    Students(rollno: integer, sname: string)
    Courses(courseno: integer, cname: string)
    Registration(rollno: integer, courseno: integer, percent: real)
Which of the following queries are equivalent to this query in English?
      "Find the distinct names of all students who score 
       more than 90% in the course numbered 107"
answerB: I, II and III only
answerC: I, II and IV only

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Given the basic ER and relational models, which of the following is INCORRECT?
answerA: An attribute of an entity can have more than one value
answerB: An attribute of an entity can be composite
answerC: In a row of a relational table, an attribute can have more than one value
answerD: In a row of a relational table, an attribute can have exactly one value or a NULL value

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Suppose (A, B) and (C,D) are two relation schemas. Let r1 and r2 be the corresponding relation instances. B is a foreign key that refers to C in r2. If data in r1 and r2 satisfy referential integrity constraints, which of the following is ALWAYS TRUE?
answerB: B
answerC: C

name: ER and Relational Models
question:
Consider the following relations A, B, C. How many tuples does the result of the following relational algebra expression contain? Assume that the schema of A U B is the same as that of A.

Table A
Id   Name    Age
----------------
12   Arun    60
15   Shreya  24
99   Rohit   11


Table B
Id   Name   Age
----------------
15   Shreya  24
25   Hari    40
98   Rohit   20
99   Rohit   11


Table C
Id   Phone  Area
-----------------
10   2200   02  
99   2100   01

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Consider a relational table r with sufficient number of records, having attributes A1, A2,…, An and let 1 <= p <= n. Two queries Q1 and Q2 are given below. The database can be configured to do ordered indexing on Ap or hashing on Ap. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
answerA: Ordered indexing will always outperform hashing for both queries
answerB: Hashing will always outperform ordered indexing for both queries
answerC: Hashing will outperform ordered indexing on Q1, but not on Q2
answerD: Hashing will outperform ordered indexing on Q2, but not on Q1.

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Which of the following tuple relational calculus expression(s) is/are equivalent to
answerB: II only
answerC: III only

name: ER and Relational Models
question: 1) Let R and S be two relations with the following schema R (P,Q,R1,R2,R3) S (P,Q,S1,S2) Where {P, Q} is the key for both schemas. Which of the following queries are equivalent?
answerB: Only I and III
answerC: Only I, II and III

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Consider the following ER diagram. The minimum number of tables needed to represent M, N, P, R1, R2 is

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Consider the data given in above question. Which of the following is a correct attribute set for one of the tables for the correct answer to the above question?

name: ER and Relational Models
question: Information about a collection of students is given by the relation studinfo(studId, name, sex). The relation enroll(studId, courseId) gives which student has enrolled for (or taken) that course(s). Assume that every course is taken by at least one male and at least one female student. What does the following relational algebra expression represent?
answerA: Courses in which all the female students are enrolled.
answerB: Courses in which a proper subset of female students are enrolled.
answerC: Courses in which only male students are enrolled.

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question: Relation R has eight attributes ABCDEFGH. Fields of R contain only atomic values. F = {CH -> G, A -> BC, B -> CFH, E -> A, F -> EG} is a set of functional dependencies (FDs) so that F+ is exactly the set of FDs that hold for R. How many candidate keys does the relation R have?

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question: Consider the FDs given in above question. The relation R is
answerB: in 2NF, but not in 3NF.
answerC: in 3NF, but not in BCNF.

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question: Which of the following is TRUE?
answerA: Every relation in 3NF is also in BCNF
answerB: A relation R is in 3NF if every non-prime attribute of R is fully functionally dependent on every key of R
answerC: Every relation in BCNF is also in 3NF
answerD: No relation can be in both BCNF and 3NF

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question:
Consider a relational table with a single record for each registered student with the following attributes.

1. Registration_Num: Unique registration number
   of each registered student
2. UID: Unique identity number, unique at the 
   national level for each citizen
3. BankAccount_Num: Unique account number at
   the bank. A student can have multiple accounts
   or join accounts. This attribute stores the 
   primary account number.
4. Name: Name of the student
5. Hostel_Room: Room number of the hostel 
Which one of the following option is INCORRECT?
answerB: Registration_Num can be a primary key
answerC: UID is candidate key if all students are from the same country
answerD: If S is a superkey such that S∩UID is NULL then S∪UID is also a superkey

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question:
Consider the following relational schema:
Suppliers(sid:integer, sname:string, city:string, street:string)
Parts(pid:integer, pname:string, color:string)
Catalog(sid:integer, pid:integer, cost:real)
Assume that, in the suppliers relation above, each supplier and each street within a city has a unique name, and (sname, city) forms a candidate key. No other functional dependencies are implied other than those implied by primary and candidate keys. Which one of the following is TRUE about the above schema?
answerB: The schema is in 3NF but not in BCNF
answerC: The schema is in 2NF but not in 3NF

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question:
Consider the following relational schemes for a library database: Book (Title, Author, Catalog_no, Publisher, Year, Price) Collection (Title, Author, Catalog_no) with in the following functional dependencies:

I. Title Author --> Catalog_no
II. Catalog_no --> Title, Author, Publisher, Year
III. Publisher Title Year --> Price 
Assume {Author, Title} is the key for both schemes. Which of the following statements is true?
answerA: Both Book and Collection are in BCNF
answerB: Both Book and Collection are in 3NF only
answerC: Book is in 2NF and Collection is in 3NF
answerD: Both Book and Collection are in 2NF only

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question: Consider the relation scheme R = {E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, M} and the set of functional dependencies {{E, F} -> {G}, {F} -> {I, J}, {E, H} -> {K, L}, K -> {M}, L -> {N} on R. What is the key for R?
answerB: {E, F, H}
answerC: {E, F, H, K, L}

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question:
Given the following two statements:

  S1: Every table with two single-valued 
      attributes is in 1NF, 2NF, 3NF and BCNF.

  S2: AB->C, D->E, E->C is a minimal cover for 
      the set of functional dependencies 
      AB->C, D->E, AB->E, E->C. 
Which one of the following is CORRECT?
answerA: S1 is TRUE and S2 is FALSE.
answerB: Both S1 and S2 are TRUE.
answerC: S1 is FALSE and S2 is TRUE.
answerD: Both S1 and S2 are FALSE.

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question: The maximum number of superkeys for the relation schema R(E,F,G,H) with E as the key is

name: Database Design(Normal Forms)
question: Given the STUDENTS relation as shown below. For (StudentName, StudentAge) to be the key for this instance, the value X should not be equal to
answerC: N/A

name: SQL
question: Which of the following statements are TRUE about an SQL query? P : An SQL query can contain a HAVING clause even if it does not have a GROUP BY clause Q : An SQL query can contain a HAVING clause only if it has a GROUP BY clause R : All attributes used in the GROUP BY clause must appear in the SELECT clause S : Not all attributes used in the GROUP BY clause need to appear in the SELECT clause
answerB: P and S
answerC: Q and R

name: SQL
question:
Table A
Id   Name    Age
----------------
12   Arun    60
15   Shreya  24
99   Rohit   11


Table B
Id   Name   Age
----------------
15   Shreya  24
25   Hari    40
98   Rohit   20
99   Rohit   11


Table C
Id   Phone  Area
-----------------
10   2200   02  
99   2100   01
Consider the above tables A, B and C. How many tuples does the result of the following SQL query contains?

SELECT A.id 
FROM   A 
WHERE  A.age > ALL (SELECT B.age 
                    FROM   B 
                    WHERE  B. name = "arun")

name: SQL
question:
Consider a database table T containing two columns X and Y each of type integer. After the creation of the table, one record (X=1, Y=1) is inserted in the table. Let MX and My denote the respective maximum values of X and Y among all records in the table at any point in time. Using MX and MY, new records are inserted in the table 128 times with X and Y values being MX+1, 2*MY+1 respectively. It may be noted that each time after the insertion, values of MX and MY change. What will be the output of the following SQL query after the steps mentioned above are carried out?

SELECT Y FROM T WHERE X=7;

name: SQL
question:
Database table by name Loan_Records is given below.
Borrower    Bank_Manager   Loan_Amount
 Ramesh      Sunderajan     10000.00
 Suresh      Ramgopal       5000.00
 Mahesh      Sunderajan     7000.00
What is the output of the following SQL query?
SELECT Count(*) 
FROM  ( (SELECT Borrower, Bank_Manager 
       FROM   Loan_Records) AS S 
        NATURAL JOIN (SELECT Bank_Manager, 
                             Loan_Amount 
                      FROM   Loan_Records) AS T );

name: SQL
question:
A relational schema for a train reservation database is given below. Passenger (pid, pname, age) Reservation (pid, class, tid)
Table: Passenger
pid   pname   age
-----------------
 0    Sachin   65
 1    Rahul    66
 2    Sourav   67
 3    Anil     69

Table : Reservation
pid  class  tid
---------------
 0    AC   8200
 1    AC   8201
 2    SC   8201
 5    AC   8203
 1    SC   8204
 3    AC   8202
What pids are returned by the following SQL query for the above instance of the tables?
SLECT pid
FROM Reservation ,
WHERE class ‘AC’ AND
    EXISTS (SELECT *
       FROM Passenger
       WHERE age > 65 AND
       Passenger. pid = Reservation.pid)

name: SQL
question:
Let R and S be relational schemes such that R={a,b,c} and S={c}. Now consider the following queries on the database:
IV) SELECT R.a, R.b
       FROM R,S
            WHERE R.c=S.c
Which of the above queries are equivalent?
answerB: I and III
answerC: II and IV

name: SQL
question:
Consider the following relational schema:
Suppliers(sid:integer, sname:string, city:string, street:string)
Parts(pid:integer, pname:string, color:string)
Catalog(sid:integer, pid:integer, cost:real)
Consider the following relational query on the above database:
SELECT S.sname
    FROM Suppliers S
        WHERE S.sid NOT IN (SELECT C.sid
                            FROM Catalog C
                            WHERE C.pid NOT IN (SELECT P.pid  
                                                FROM Parts P
                                                WHERE P.color<> 'blue'))
Assume that relations corresponding to the above schema are not empty. Which one of the following is the correct interpretation of the above query?
answerA: Find the names of all suppliers who have supplied a non-blue part.
answerB: Find the names of all suppliers who have not supplied a non-blue part.
answerC: Find the names of all suppliers who have supplied only blue parts.
answerD: Find the names of all suppliers who have not supplied only blue parts.

name: SQL
question:
Consider the table employee(empId, name, department, salary) and the two queries Q1 ,Q2 below. Assuming that department 5 has more than one employee, and we want to find the employees who get higher salary than anyone in the department 5, which one of the statements is TRUE for any arbitrary employee table?

Q1 : Select e.empId
     From employee e
     Where not exists
        (Select * From employee s where s.department = “5” and 
                                        s.salary >=e.salary)
Q2 : Select e.empId
     From employee e
     Where e.salary > Any
    (Select distinct salary From employee s Where s.department = “5”)
answerB: Q2 is the correct query
answerC: Both Q1 and Q2 produce the same answer.
answerD: Neither Q1 nor Q2 is the correct query

name: SQL
question:
Given the following statements:

    S1: A foreign key declaration can always 
        be replaced by an equivalent check
        assertion in SQL.
    S2: Given the table R(a,b,c) where a and
        b together form the primary key, the 
        following is a valid table definition.
        CREATE TABLE S (
            a INTEGER,
            d INTEGER,
            e INTEGER,
            PRIMARY KEY (d),
            FOREIGN KEY (a) references R) 
Which one of the following statements is CORRECT?
answerA: S1 is TRUE and S2 is FALSE.
answerB: Both S1 and S2 are TRUE.
answerC: S1 is FALSE and S2 is TRUE.
answerD: Both S1 and S2 are FALSE.

name: SQL
question:
Given the following schema:

     employees(emp-id, first-name, last-name, hire-date, dept-id, salary)
     departments(dept-id, dept-name, manager-id, location-id) 
You want to display the last names and hire dates of all latest hires in their respective departments in the location ID 1700. You issue the following query:

SQL> SELECT last-name, hire-date
     FROM employees
     WHERE (dept-id, hire-date) IN
     (SELECT dept-id, MAX(hire-date)
     FROM employees JOIN departments USING(dept-id)
     WHERE location-id = 1700
     GROUP BY dept-id); 
What is the outcome?
answerA: It executes but does not give the correct result.
answerB: It executes and gives the correct result.
answerC: It generates an error because of pairwise comparison.
answerD: It generates an error because the GROUP BY clause cannot be used with table joins in a subquery

name: Transactions and concurrency control
answerB: A schedule that is not conflict serializable
answerC: A conflict serializable schedule
answerD: A schedule for which a precedence graph cannot be drawn

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question: Which of the following concurrency control protocols ensure both conflict serialzability and freedom from deadlock? I. 2-phase locking II. Time-stamp ordering
answerB: II only
answerC: Both I and II

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question: Consider the following schedule for transactions T1, T2 and T3: Which one of the schedules below is the correct serialization of the above?

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question: Consider the following four schedules due to three transactions (indicated by the subscript) using read and write on a data item x, denoted by r(x) and w(x) respectively. Which one of them is conflict serializable.
answerB: B
answerC: C

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question: Consider the following schedule S of transactions T1, T2, T3, T4: Which one of the following statements is CORRECT?
answerA: S is conflict-serializable but not recoverable
answerB: S is not conflict-serializable but is recoverable
answerC: S is both conflict-serializable and recoverable
answerD: S is neither conflict-serializable nor is it recoverable

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question:
Consider the transactions T1, T2, and T3 and the schedules S1 and S2 given below.

T1: r1(X); r1(Z); w1(X); w1(Z)
T2: r2(Y); r2(Z); w2(Z)
T3: r3(Y); r3(X); w3(Y)
S1: r1(X); r3(Y); r3(X); r2(Y); r2(Z);
    w3(Y); w2(Z); r1(Z); w1(X); w1(Z)
S2: r1(X); r3(Y); r2(Y); r3(X); r1(Z);
    r2(Z); w3(Y); w1(X); w2(Z); w1(Z) 
Which one of the following statements about the schedules is TRUE?
answerB: Only S2 is conflict-serializable.
answerC: Both S1 and S2 are conflict-serializable.
answerD: Neither S1 nor S2 is conflict-serializable.

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question:
Consider the following log sequence of two transactions on a bank account, with initial balance 12000, that transfer 2000 to a mortgage payment and then apply a 5% interest.

  1. T1 start
  2. T1 B old=12000 new=10000
  3. T1 M old=0 new=2000
  4. T1 commit
  5. T2 start
  6. T2 B old=10000 new=10500
  7. T2 commit 
Suppose the database system cra shes just before log record 7 is written. When the system is restarted, which one statement is true of the recovery procedure?
answerA: We must redo log record 6 to set B to 10500
answerB: We must undo log record 6 to set B to 10000 and then redo log records 2 and 3.
answerC: We need not redo log records 2 and 3 because transaction T1 has committed.
answerD: We can apply redo and undo operations in arbitrary order because they are idempotent

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question: Which of the following scenarios may lead to an irrecoverable error in a database system ?
answerA: A transaction writes a data item after it is read by an uncommitted transaction
answerB: A transaction reads a data item after it is read by an uncommitted transaction
answerC: A transaction reads a data item after it is written by a committed transaction
answerD: A transaction reads a data item after it is written by an uncommitted transaction

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question: Consider three data items D1, D2 and D3 and the following execution schedule of transactions T1, T2 and T3. In the diagram, R(D) and W(D) denote the actions reading and writing the data item D respectively. Which of the following statements is correct?
answerA: The schedule is serializable as T2; T3; T1
answerB: The schedule is serializable as T2; T1; T3
answerC: The schedule is serializable as T3; T2; T1

name: Transactions and concurrency control
question:
Consider the following transaction involving two bank accounts x and y.

read(x);  x := x – 50;  write(x);  read(y);  y := y + 50;  write(y) 
The constraint that the sum of the accounts x and y should remain constant is that of
answerB: Consistency
answerC: Isolation

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: An index is clustered, if
answerA: it is on a set of fields that form a candidate key.
answerB: it is on a set of fields that include the primary key.
answerC: the data records of the file are organized in the same order as the data entries of the index.
answerD: the data records of the file are organized not in the same order as the data entries of the index.

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: Consider a B+-tree in which the maximum number of keys in a node is 5. What is the minimum number of keys in any non-root node?

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: A clustering index is defined on the fields which are of type
answerB: non-key and non-ordering
answerC: key and ordering

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: A FAT (file allocation table) based file system is being used and the total overhead of each entry in the FAT is 4 bytes in size. Given a 100 x 106 bytes disk on which the file system is stored and data block size is 103 bytes, the maximum size of a file that can be stored on this disk in units of 106 bytes is ____________.

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: In the index allocation scheme of blocks to a file, the maximum possible size of the file depends on :
answerA: the size of the blocks, and the size of the ad­dress of the blocks.
answerB: the number of blocks used for the index, and the size of the blocks.
answerC: the size of the blocks, the number of blocks used for the index, and the size of the address of the blocks.

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: A file is organized so that the ordering of data records is the same as or close to the ordering of data entries in some index. Then that index is called
answerB: Sparse
answerC: Clustered

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: Q 82_Part A A database table T1 has 2000 records and occupies 80 disk blocks. Another table T2 has 400 records and occupies 20 disk blocks. These two tables have to be joined as per a specified join condition that needs to be evaluated for every pair of records from these two tables. The memory buffer space available can hold exactly one block of records for T1 and one block of records for T2 simultaneously at any point in time. No index is available on either table. If Nested-loop join algorithm is employed to perform the join, with the most appropriate choice of table to be used in outer loop, the number of block accesses required for reading the data are

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: Q82_Part B A database table T1 has 2000 records and occupies 80 disk blocks. Another table T2 has 400 records and occupies 20 disk blocks. These two tables have to be joined as per a specified join condition that needs to be evaluated for every pair of records from these two tables. The memory buffer space available can hold exactly one block of records for T1 and one block of records for T2 simultaneously at any point in time. No index is available on either table. If, instead of Nested-loop join, Block nested-loop join is used, again with the most appropriate choice of table in the outer loop, the reduction in number of block accesses required for reading the data will be

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question: Which of the following is correct?
answerA: B-trees are for storing data on disk and B+ trees are for main memory.
answerB: Range queries are faster on B+ trees.
answerC: B-trees are for primary indexes and B+ trees are for secondary indexes.
answerD: The height of a B+ tree is independent of the number of records.

name: File structures (sequential files, indexing, B and B+ trees)
question:
There are 5 records in a database.

Name     Age    Occupation    Category
Rama     27       CON            A
Abdul    22       ENG            A
Jeniffer 28       DOC            B
Maya     32       SER            D
Dev      24       MUS            C
There is an index file associated with this and it contain the values 1, 3, 2, 5 and 4. Which one of the fields is the index built form?
answerB: Name
answerC: Occupation
